articles.headline: Young African Migrants Caught in Trafficking Machine
articles.snippet: Unaccompanied children are among the most innocent victims of the trafficking machine that is sucking migrants into Libya’s maelstrom and out onto the Mediterranean.
articles.abstract: Unaccompanied children are among the most innocent victims of the trafficking machine that is sucking migrants into Libya’s maelstrom and out onto the Mediterranean.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAWIYAH, Libya — The no-money-down offer was too tempting for the children to resist.

articles.headline: Air Ambulances Offer a Lifeline, and Then a Sky-High Bill
articles.snippet: Squeezed by competition and insurance cuts, air ambulance companies are increasingly pressing patients to make up sometimes sizable shortfalls.
articles.abstract: Squeezed by competition and insurance cuts, air ambulance companies are increasingly pressing patients to make up sometimes sizable shortfalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: Clarence W. Kendall, a rancher in Pearce, Ariz., was moving bales on top of a haystack when he fell eight feet and struck his head on the corner of a truck below. His health insurance covered most of the cost of treating the head trauma caused by the accident.

articles.headline: What the Debate on Inequality Is Missing
articles.snippet: The quarreling in Washington about taxes and spending ignores some areas in which policies actually promote unequal distribution of wealth.
articles.abstract: The quarreling in Washington about taxes and spending ignores some areas in which policies actually promote unequal distribution of wealth.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy is one of the most effective on earth in terms of generating new wealth. But for all the wealth it generates, it does an exceptionally dismal job at sharing it broadly among Americans.

articles.headline: ‘Galactic Hot Dogs’ Hopes Readers on Funbrain Will Buy at Bookstores
articles.snippet: Max Brallier’s “Galactic Hot Dogs” has taken off on the gaming website for children, leading to a seven-figure, three-book deal with Aladdin, an imprint of Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing.
articles.abstract: Max Brallier’s “Galactic Hot Dogs” has taken off on the gaming website for children, leading to a seven-figure, three-book deal with Aladdin, an imprint of Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Max Brallier didn’t have very realistic career goals as a child.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s Appeal Survives Scrutiny, Poll Says
articles.snippet: The New York Times/CBS News survey also found that Republican voters were most open to considering Senator Marco Rubio, Mike Huckabee and Jeb Bush for president.
articles.abstract: The New York Times/CBS News survey also found that Republican voters were most open to considering Senator Marco Rubio, Mike Huckabee and Jeb Bush for president.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton appears to have initially weathered a barrage of news about her use of a private email account when she was secretary of state and the practices of her family’s foundation, an indication that she is starting her second presidential bid with an unusual durability among Democratic voters.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Bankers and Regulators Voice Fears on Bond Market Volatility
articles.snippet: Some Wall Street chiefs and banking watchdogs warn that turbulence in the bond market could make it harder for companies and countries to borrow.
articles.abstract: Some Wall Street chiefs and banking watchdogs warn that turbulence in the bond market could make it harder for companies and countries to borrow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street chieftains, huge investment firms and top bank regulators are all sounding the same alarm.

articles.headline: Dollar’s Rise Lifts Imports and Widens Trade Gap
articles.snippet: Experts say that a chronic gap between imports and exports could impede a generally improving economy.
articles.abstract: Experts say that a chronic gap between imports and exports could impede a generally improving economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: A roof-raising trade gap in March highlighted concerns that the rise of the dollar against other currencies was weakening the economy, chipping away at the ability of American manufacturers to compete abroad while encouraging more imports to fill retailers’ shelves.

articles.headline: Now, Spotlight Turns to AT&T-DirecTV Deal
articles.snippet: The AT&T-DirecTV deal has largely avoided scrutiny while a proposed Comcast-Time Warner merger was in the works. Until now.
articles.abstract: The AT&T-DirecTV deal has largely avoided scrutiny while a proposed Comcast-Time Warner merger was in the works. Until now.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just three months after Comcast announced its $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable last year, its rival AT&T announced a $48 billion takeover of DirecTV.

articles.headline: Al Jazeera America, Its Newsroom in Turmoil, Is Now the News
articles.snippet: A lawsuit and an exodus of top executives have revealed grievances that employees say reflect a deep dysfunction in management of the newsroom.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit and an exodus of top executives have revealed grievances that employees say reflect a deep dysfunction in management of the newsroom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly two years ago, Ehab Al Shihabi, the chief executive of Al Jazeera America, took the stage at the Aspen Ideas Festival and proposed something grand: An American cable news station that would be thoughtful, probing and smart.

articles.headline: Police Struggle With Loss of Privileged Position
articles.snippet: Amid a rash of high-profile incidents involving allegations of police overreach, police unions are trying to adapt to a rapidly changing political context.
articles.abstract: Amid a rash of high-profile incidents involving allegations of police overreach, police unions are trying to adapt to a rapidly changing political context.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early this year, Megan E. Green, a St. Louis alderwoman, met with officials of a local police union to discuss a proposal for a civilian oversight board that would look into accusations of police misconduct. After Ms. Green refused to soften her support for the proposal, the union backed an aggressive mailing campaign against her.

articles.headline: Two Retail Veterans Take Aim at Amazon’s E-Commerce Reign
articles.snippet: The start-ups Enjoy and Jet.com are hoping to knock Amazon off its perch as the leader of online shopping.
articles.abstract: The start-ups Enjoy and Jet.com are hoping to knock Amazon off its perch as the leader of online shopping.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — There are two ways for start-ups to take on Amazon, the reigning monarch of American online shopping.

articles.headline: E.U. Commission Opens Antitrust Inquiry Into E-Commerce Sector
articles.snippet: Officials said the investigation would address whether large players like American tech giants were impeding competition for European consumers.
articles.abstract: Officials said the investigation would address whether large players like American tech giants were impeding competition for European consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — European officials on Wednesday opened an antitrust investigation into whether large technology companies were impeding competition in online shopping, the latest in a string of inquiries in Europe focused on the web’s biggest players.

articles.headline: E.C.B. Doubts Add to Uncertainties on Greek Debt Lifeline
articles.snippet: The European Central Bank has already lent about $120 billion to Greek banks, which need the cash to continue providing credit to the economy.
articles.abstract: The European Central Bank has already lent about $120 billion to Greek banks, which need the cash to continue providing credit to the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — As Greece mounts an 11th-hour diplomatic offensive across Europe to secure financial aid that it desperately needs to avoid a default, patience with Athens is wearing thin at the European Central Bank.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Shooting Clouds Life as Both Muslim and Texan
articles.snippet: The attack at a gathering that showcased caricatures depicting the Prophet Muhammad has prompted Muslims to condemn extremism of any kind while also questioning when free speech becomes hate speech.
articles.abstract: The attack at a gathering that showcased caricatures depicting the Prophet Muhammad has prompted Muslims to condemn extremism of any kind while also questioning when free speech becomes hate speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: GARLAND, Tex. — When Muslim leaders in the Dallas area learned in February that a provocative blogger had rented space to exhibit caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad, they decided to ignore her.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Laurie Goodstein
